Agency: Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement
Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement
Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement
Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement

Description: Anadarko Petroleum Co. and two related oil production companies agreed to pay a civil penalty of more than $1 million and implement injunctive relief, develop facility response plans, and revise spill prevention as well as containment plans at a cost of more than $8 million during the term of the settlement in order to resolve violations of the Clean Water Act.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: A settlement reached with Anadarko Petroleum Corp.and Kerr McGee went into effect, allowing funds to be disbursed for cleanups across the country. This settlement resolved fraudulent conveyance claims brought by the United States and the Anadarko Litigation Trust, the trust against Anadarko Petroleum Corporation and its affiliates, the defendants, in the bankruptcy of Tronox Inc. and its subsidiaries.  The defendants paid $5.15 billion, plus interest, to the trust.  The trust was expected to distribute more than $4.4 billion to fund environmental clean-up and for environmental claims.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Description: During the course of a BSEE inspection, it was discovered that the pit level alarm was disabled and the flow show alarm was also disabled.
Agency: Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement

Description: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Kerr-McGee Corporation and their affiliates agreed to pay the United States more than $17 million to resolve claims that the companies violated the False Claims Act by knowingly underpaying royalties owed on natural gas produced from federal and Indian leases, and numerous additional administrative claims.

During a BSEE incident investigation, it was discovered that Anardarko failed to develop and use a management system for operation of the subsea BOP system, which includes procedures for prevention of accidental or unplanned disconnects of the system. It was also found that the driller's energized BOP panel was accessed with ongoing wireline operations in the well bore. No JSA had been developed and no Permit to Work had been issued because appropriate personnel were not aware of the action.  Dec. 8, 2011 - Feb.19, 2012; Feb. 19, 2012
Agency: Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement

Description: During the course of a BSEE investigation involving injuries, it was discovered that a composite air pressure vessel exploded causing a large fireball and flying shrapnel, followed by a venting sound. The Subsea personnel were injured, receiving second and third degree burns from the flash fire.  November 2, 2013
Agency: Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement
Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration

Description: Kerr-McGee Corp. agreed to spend $18 million on pollution controls as part of a Clean Air Act settlement covering facilities across Utah and Colorado. In addition to implementing pollution controls, the agreement required Kerr-McGee to pay a $200,000 penalty and spend $250,000 on environmental projects to benefit the areas in which the violations occurred.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: Kerr-McGee Corporation agreed to pay $13 million to resolve claims under the False Claims Act and administrative claims that the corporation underpaid royalties due for oil produced on federal and Indian leases from 1988 to 1998.

Agency: Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement

Description: Occidental Petroleum Corporation, Occidental Oil and Gas Corporation, and OXY USA Inc. agreed to pay the United States $2.05 million plus interest to resolve claims that the companies violated the False Claims Act by knowingly underpaying royalties owed on natural gas produced from federal leases.

Oxy Vinyls agreed to significantly reduce vinyl chloride emissions at its plants in Pasadena, Texas; Deer Park, Texas; Louisville, Ky; and Pedricktown, N.J.  and to perform three environmental projects at an estimated cost of $1.2 million that are expected to permanently decrease emissions of vinyl chloride by approximately 40,000 pounds per year within five years. The company also agreed to pay a civil penalty of $70,000 to the federal government.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Company: Kerr McGee Chemical and Hydrovac Industrial Services
Description: Kerr McGee and Hydrovac agreed to pay a total of $138,000 in settlement of allegations they discharged creosote and diesel in the Little Sac River during demolition of a wood treating facility.

Kerr-McGee Chemical, LLC agreed to pay up to $100,000 for the state's costs of reviewing and overseeing restoration plans, in settlement of alleged environmental violations at its former rare earths facility.
Notes: The settlement also included a $200,000 payment to the United States Department of the Interior.

Description: A New Jersey Superior Court judge approved a $190 million settlement with Occidental Chemical Corporation that resolved the company's liability for contamination of the Passaic River.
